subject: Re: New member hello
author: mercifulrelease
full_text:
Hi Misty,

Thanks for the luck :-)  I am familiar with ufogeek's YouTube videos
and he does provide a lot of information.  I had not heard of Steve
Hultay and will look him up when I get a chance.  I am familiar with
the Radio Shack hack radios and manual tune methods.  I still want to
build my own though :-)  I'm an EE and it's kind of a pride thing. 
Plus, I can explain the data better if I'm using a device I actually
understand and can poke and prod as needed.  The dead zone is a good
idea and not something I've heard of before.  This might be a dumb
question, but has anyone experimented with pure (white, pink, etc.)
noise as a source for collecting EVP?

I look forward to hearing the samples you all have collected...

Anna


--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "Misty" <bulletbabea@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Anna
> 
> Welcome to the group. Good luck on building your box. I guess the 
> first easiest place to direct you would be Mike Coletta's website. He 
> has posted alot of DIY how-to videos for newbies on how to modify a 
> radio yourself to work similar to Franks boxes. His youtube page has 
> most of that stuff but his websites interesting to keep up with as 
> well =) 
> 
> http://www.youtube.com/ufogeek
> http://www.ufomagazine.net/
> 
> (Thanks for posting those again Mike)
> 
> While your on youtube you may want to check out some other peoples 
> videos on how to modify an existing radio. Franks modified a number 
> of different types as have others like Steve Hultay. Steve posted a 
> list of the ones he's been able to modify. Usually it requires 
> nothing more than snipping  the mute wire. The archives on this group 
> are a wealth of information just use the keyword search.
> 
> You also may want to try out manual sweep Most people find that 
> brings in very good results. For manual sweep you are just sweeping 
> the band. I prefer to use a radio with a knob dial. Then just start 
> turning it back and forth across the band quickly so it doesnt have 
> quite enough time to tune in any one radio station.
> 
> I also have had quite a bit of success using a dead zone spot in 
> between any stations so that its set to off station and all I hear 
> live is the radios static/whir. I have posted examples of some of 
> these methods off my website.
> 
> http://misty.xm.com
> 
> Good luck on your quest!
> Misty
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "mercifulrelease" 
> <mercifulrelease@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Everyone!
> > 
> > I'm new and I stumbled onto this group after doing some research
> > online into EVP.  I consider myself to be a paranormal skeptic, but 
> I
> > have heard some very interesting EVP evidence and would like to look
> > into it further.  I joined this group because I am interested in
> > submitting EVP data to some rigorous scientific analysis.  I'm an
> > electrical engineer and mainly work in the areas of signal 
> processing
> > and communications so all of this is extremely interesting.  
> > 
> > I am interested in collecting some of my own data (at some point) by
> > building a ghost box based on Frank Sumption's designs.  I am 
> working
> > from the "Ghost Box Notebook" from 2007, but I am having a hard time
> > getting started.  Has anyone built one of these and are there any
> > parts lists or more complete schematics floating around? I would
> > appreciate any build help or advice any of you might have.
> > 
> > Regards,
> > 
> > Anna
> >
>
